Line 38: Line 38:
Johnston Hall serves many purposes for the University of Guelph; however, it is primarily used as a residence hall. It accommodates 315 students, which live on the top three floors of the building. Johnston Hall is known for its traditional architecture, and its spacious tower lounge makes it a favorite among students <ref>Canadian Universities (2010). Profile of Johnston Hall, University of Guelph. http://www.canadian-universities.net/Campus/Residence246.html. Retrieved June 30, 2010.</ref>. It is considered a medium-sized residence, and is one of the most desired residences on campus. In fact, the University receives thousands of applications, with students making Johnston Hall their first choice, but only 315 get in. The process works on a lottery basis, and each student has an equal advantage as long as they have applied before the deadline set by the University of Guelph.
Johnston Hall serves many purposes for the University of Guelph; however, it is primarily used as a residence hall. It accommodates 315 students, which live on the top three floors of the building. Johnston Hall is known for its traditional architecture, and its spacious tower lounge makes it a favorite among students <ref>Canadian Universities (2010). Profile of Johnston Hall, University of Guelph. http://www.canadian-universities.net/Campus/Residence246.html. Retrieved June 30, 2010.</ref>. It is considered a medium-sized residence, and is one of the most desired residences on campus. In fact, the University receives thousands of applications, with students making Johnston Hall their first choice, but only 315 get in. The process works on a lottery basis, and each student has an equal advantage as long as they have applied before the deadline set by the University of Guelph.
â
[[Image:theportico.jpg|thumb|upright=1.28|left|This is the piece of the Portico that remained after the old building was demolished in 1928. Photo courtesy of the [[University of Guelph]]]].
+
[[File:NonFreeImageRemoved.svg|thumb|upright=1.28|left|This is the piece of the Portico that remained after the old building was demolished in 1928. Photo courtesy of the [[University of Guelph]]]].
'''Academically Enriched Environment'''<br />
'''Academically Enriched Environment'''<br />
Line 113: Line 113:
The building is designed with rooms running off both sides of the corridor on each floor. Rooms are primarily doubles or triples, with the exception of a few singles on each floor. In addition, the rooms are laid out to have male and female designated rooms side by side. Although Johnston Hall is a co-ed residence, it does not have co-ed rooms (where males and females share the same room). Additionally, the rooms are set up by degree program. Each year, administration attempts to position all science students or business students on one floor, or at least in one entire section of a floor, depending on the variability of programs. This is done to facilitate team-building and students helping each other out with academics.
The building is designed with rooms running off both sides of the corridor on each floor. Rooms are primarily doubles or triples, with the exception of a few singles on each floor. In addition, the rooms are laid out to have male and female designated rooms side by side. Although Johnston Hall is a co-ed residence, it does not have co-ed rooms (where males and females share the same room). Additionally, the rooms are set up by degree program. Each year, administration attempts to position all science students or business students on one floor, or at least in one entire section of a floor, depending on the variability of programs. This is done to facilitate team-building and students helping each other out with academics.
â
[[Image:Johnstonfloorplan.JPG|thumb|upright=1.3|right|This is a floor plan of a standard double room. Photo courtesy of the [[University of Guelph]]]].
+
[[File:NonFreeImageRemoved.svg|thumb|upright=1.3|right|This is a floor plan of a standard double room. Photo courtesy of the [[University of Guelph]]]].
The building has two large separate male and female washrooms on each floor and a small kitchenette/study lounge. The lounge includes such items as a microwave, sink, cabinets, and study cubicles, as well as a dining room table/bench. All rooms are equipped with twin-sized single mattresses and large dressers, bookshelves, and a wooden desk with a lamp. Some of the triple rooms contain new furniture including bunk beds, smaller but more spacious desks and cabinets. Rooms do not come with linen, bedspreads, pillows, or towels.
The building has two large separate male and female washrooms on each floor and a small kitchenette/study lounge. The lounge includes such items as a microwave, sink, cabinets, and study cubicles, as well as a dining room table/bench. All rooms are equipped with twin-sized single mattresses and large dressers, bookshelves, and a wooden desk with a lamp. Some of the triple rooms contain new furniture including bunk beds, smaller but more spacious desks and cabinets. Rooms do not come with linen, bedspreads, pillows, or towels.
Line 123: Line 123:
Johnston Hall is one of the only residences at the University of Guelph with cameras in all hallways. These cameras are 360-degree cameras without volume. They are installed into the ceiling panels, usually 2-3 cameras per straight hallway. The cameras are not monitored on a 24-hour basis, but used as a precautionary measure in case an incident does occur. Having said that, Johnston Hall is locked on a 24-hour basis, and residents need to use their key to enter the building, and another key to enter their residence room and mailbox. In terms of accessibility, Johnston Hall is a handicap friendly building, which is serviced by one elevator that can only be used by occupants with a designated key. Otherwise, most students use the wide stair cases located in nearly every hallway.
Johnston Hall is one of the only residences at the University of Guelph with cameras in all hallways. These cameras are 360-degree cameras without volume. They are installed into the ceiling panels, usually 2-3 cameras per straight hallway. The cameras are not monitored on a 24-hour basis, but used as a precautionary measure in case an incident does occur. Having said that, Johnston Hall is locked on a 24-hour basis, and residents need to use their key to enter the building, and another key to enter their residence room and mailbox. In terms of accessibility, Johnston Hall is a handicap friendly building, which is serviced by one elevator that can only be used by occupants with a designated key. Otherwise, most students use the wide stair cases located in nearly every hallway.

Line 169: Line 169: â
[[Image:jhallcannon.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.3|A picture of Old Jeremiah painted in traditional Johnston colors by some residents of the Hall. Photo courtesy of [[Facebook]]]].
+
[[File:NonFreeImageRemoved.svg|thumb|left|upright=1.3|A picture of Old Jeremiah painted in traditional Johnston colors by some residents of the Hall. Photo courtesy of [[Facebook]]]].
Not only is Johnston Green a place where people get together, but it also holds some of the Universityâs historical landmarks. Old Jeremiah (the cannon) was once relocated on Johnston Green during the 1970âs but has since been moved back onto Winegard Walk where it still resides. Another landmark that sits on Johnston Green is The Portico. The Portico has existed since 1874 when the first students walked through it as it was the door to the house of Frederick W. Stone. Eventually the University purchased the building to use it as a lecture hall and a residence building. The building was torn down to make way for Johnston Hall, and The Portico was saved and moved onto Johnston Green as a commemorative item. Guelph alumni certainly enjoy the sentimentality of The Portico. This landmark is also a popular are for students to take their graduation photos.
